contentrichtext.text: {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2012}} '''Yakov Izrailevich Zak''' ({{lang-uk|Яків Ізраїлович Зак}}), ({{lang-ru|link=no|Яков Израилевич Зак}}), ''Jiakov Israilevič Sak''; [[Odessa]], {{OldStyleDate|20 November|1913|7 November}} – Moscow, 28 June 1976) was a Soviet pianist and teacher of Jewish extraction. Born in [[Odessa]], Zak studied piano at the Odessa Conservatory with Maria Starkhova, took classes on special [[harmony]] with [[Mykola Vilinsky]], and later studied with [[Heinrich Neuhaus]] in Moscow, graduating in 1935.<ref name="Baker's Bio">{{cite book|last=Slonimsky|first=Nicolas|title=Baker's Biographical dictionary of musicians|year=1978|publisher=Schirmer Books|location=New York|isbn=0-02-870240-9|edition=6th|page=1935|chapter=Zak, Yakov}}</ref> Having made his debut in 1935, he rose to prominence when he won First Prize and the Mazurka Prize at the [[International Frederick Chopin Piano Competition]] in 1937. From 1935 Zak taught at the [[Moscow Conservatory]], becoming a professor in 1947 and being granted a chair in 1965. His pupils include [[Nikolai Petrov]], [[Evgeny Mogilevsky]], Lubov Timofeyeva, [[Valery Afanassiev]], [[Ludmila Knezkova-Hussey]] and [[Youri Egorov]]. In 1966 Yakov Zak was made [[People's Artist of the USSR]]. == References == {{reflist}} #[http://en.chopin.nifc.pl/chopin/persons/detail/id/2832 Yakov Zak, biography] #Yakov Zak, Stat'i, Materialy, Vospominaniia (Papers, Documents, Memoirs), Moscow, "Sovetskii Kompozitor", 1980 [http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/8455225&referer=brief_results] #[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RfUU4Bal6c8 Yakov Zak plays Chopin – Sonata no.3 in B minor, op.58] {{Authority control|VIAF=20908019}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Zak, Yakov | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Soviet pianist | DATE OF BIRTH = 1913 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = 1976 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Zak, Yakov}} [[Category:1913 births]] [[Category:1976 deaths]] [[Category:Soviet classical pianists]] [[Category:International Chopin Piano Competition winners]] [[Category:People's Artists of the USSR]] [[Category:People from Odessa]] [[Category:Russian Jews]] [[Category:Ukrainian Jews]]
